metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Notes from the Eye of the Storm: Trainees at the Frontlines of the COVID-19 Pandemic Notes from the Eye of the Storm: Trainees at the Frontlines of the COVID-19 Pandemic Brief title: Trainees at the Frontlines of the COVID-19 Pandemic

abstract.text: There were no relationships with any industry members.

body_text.text: The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that has changed our world in an unprecedented way. As cases throughout the USA are steadily rising, we are only now getting a picture of its true extent. The numbers are staggering, and healthcare systems are struggling under the burden of this rapidly spreading disease. In this situation, it would be easy to forget how the pandemic is affecting the physical and emotional lives of residents and fellows, who are at the front lines of this battle. However, thanks to traditional and social media, the situation of the HCW has now come into the spotlight and many have even begun to consider the impact this pandemic will have on the training of residents and fellows.

NYC, where our hospital is located, is now the epicenter of the pandemic -with over 150,000 cases and 15,000 deaths (1) . Despite a gradual decline in the number of daily new cases, we are operating at maximum capacity. With rooms in the ED now fully occupied with COVID-19 patients waiting for hospital beds, stretchers are lined up wherever there is space and many hospitals have tents outside their EDs to house additional patients. Some are being transferred to the nearby Javits Convention Center, which has been converted into a field hospital, and others to the USNS Comfort docked on the Hudson River.

Due to the active community spread of the infection, any patient with a cough and fever may have the virus and seemingly healthy patients can be carriers. Thus, ours and other hospitals now require the use of masks when interacting with patients. Yet due to limited supplies precious N95 masks and face shields are limited and just one of each are given to providers each day.

Further, the hospital has been broadly divided into non-COVID and COVID areas, with the latter now forming the vast majority. All ICUs (cardiac or surgical) are now COVID ICUs, and temporary ICUs have been created on medicine floors, in peri-operative spaces and even endoscopy suites and all HCWs, regardless of their prior roles, are now taking care of hospitalized COVID patients In this situation, it has been especially challenging for specialists providing advanced services. For instance, last month, during the initial surge of patients, due to lack of resuscitation rooms, we received a patient presenting with a STEMI in a makeshift curtained-off room in the ED, before rushing her to our catheterization laboratory. STEMI patients often present in extremis, which is why they are brought to the resuscitation rooms first. But that night, this was not an option, it was touch-and-go, but we were lucky that all went well. Despite the surprising fall in the number of STEMIs presenting to our hospital during the pandemic, every new case presents a similar logistical challenge. It is not just because of a lack of space to triage patients, but also due to the fact that time-sensitive therapies of STEMI management need to be counterbalanced against the time and care that are required to deploy PPE, don gear and ensure isolation precautions to protect the staff -(any new patient could have COVID-19).

With the surge of hospitalizations for COVID, all elective procedures, tests, and clinic visits have been postponed to conserve hospital resources, re-allocate personnel, and reduce potential exposure for patients and staff. Yet fellowship training in cardiovascular diseases relies heavily on experience in interpreting echocardiograms, nuclear tests, and other imaging studies as well as performing cardiac catheterizations and electrophysiology procedures. Since the vast majority of these are elective, they have been canceled. Additionally, outpatient clinics, a key component of a fellow's clinical training, have also been suspended, and replaced by the rare tele-health visit. This may have less of an effect on fellows engaged in three years of training, who might be able to make up for lost time in the subsequent years, however, this is especially problematic for our procedure based specialty fellows, such as interventional and electrophysiology fellows whose training is only 1-2 years. Interventional fellows are required to perform 400 procedures (ACGME) and 250 procedures (ABIM) before graduation (2, 3) .

Electrophysiology fellows are required to perform 160 catheter ablations, 100 implantations of cardiac electrical devices, and 30 device replacements/revisions (4, 5) . Assuming up to 2 months of lost time in the labs during this pandemic, it is estimated that the total number of cases performed will be reduced by 20%. Trainees at programs that provide only the minimal requisite number of cases, may not meet the required numbers this year. Additionally, a procedural based trainee, generally gains the most experience in fellowship at the end of their year of training when they operate with more independence. Yet, during the last months of this year, fellows, like most, are instead working as medical residents in COVID wards. Additionally, national, international conferences and local conferences including grand rounds and morning reports have been cancelled. Programs are making efforts to move these conferences to a virtual platform. However, due to competing clinical demands, there has been limited time for trainees to attend these conferences.

House staff who have become symptomatic have been quarantined at home. This has been a complicated situation for those working in NYC who often live in small apartments. Even those who are well worry about transmitting the virus to their loved ones and have considered living away from them; given the indefinite duration of this pandemic, for many it is unreasonable to consider living apart. Some trainees have indeed chosen to live apart from their families at great personal expense, others have tried to be especially diligent about distancing themselves while at home, and still others have accepted the possibility of transmitting the infection and hoping that they develop immunity. Some of the more stressful situations are those of pregnant house staff, who have concerns that this virus may not only cause harm to themselves but also to their unborn child. Many of our house staff have gotten ill, but have ultimately recovered. Sadly, the pandemic has taken the lives of members of the system's wider health care community including a nurse and a technician very dear to our trainees. These great losses have taken an emotional toll on all. Residents and fellows rely on their friends and families for emotional support. But given the social distancing in place, these support networks have become strained. Some are experiencing depression, anxiety, insomnia, and distress, just as were seen in many HCWs early in the pandemic in China (6).

It goes without saying that the most suffering during this pandemic is being endured by our patients. Apart from the suffering brought on by COVID itself, patients have to endure many other ordeals. They are isolated and alone and only see their providers through layers of face shields, masks and other protective gear. Further, to limit exposure to HCWs, direct patient interactions are reserved for essential issues. The tragedy of this pandemic is that the necessity of every treatment and therapy for the patient has to be measured against the safety of HCWs. At no time is this more evident than when a patient is in extremis or goes into cardiac arrest. The need to gain rapid access to the patient and institute life-saving and resuscitative measures is sharply at odds with the time and care needed to doff protective gear and ensure isolation precautions.

But isolation has taken on a whole new meaning in this pandemic. Patients say goodbye to loved ones at the door of the ED because families are no longer allowed to visit. Patients often spend weeks in the hospital alone, only communicating with their loved ones over the phone or by video chat; and some patients may not even have this facility. Many patients have suffered and died in the hospital without their families at their bedside. HCWs have tried their utmost to help keep families in touch; in our ICU we are in contact with relatives sometimes several times a day, and we have tablets to help families see their loved ones when possible.
For us, the suffering of patients and their families is cause for great anguish and the scale of the hardships brought upon our patients will no doubt have a lasting impact.

The ACGME has allowed programs to self-declare a Pandemic Emergency Status which permits all medical trainees to care for patients in EDs, ICUs, and on patient floors, regardless of their designated training track. As such the ACGME and ABIM acknowledges that even if a resident or fellow is unable to complete all rotations, they will be eligible to graduate and sit for the boards providing the trainee has otherwise demonstrated competence in their area of specialty and can practice independently.

Thus, our training and education must evolve during the pandemic. While we cannot lose focus on the task at hand -battling this disease and providing the highest quality of care to our patients -some creative steps and thoughtful measures need to be taken to ensure the continuity of resident and fellow education. Trainees need to continue to receive dedicated education and training in their specialties, in small, but hopefully meaningful ways. For example, our cardiovascular department has implemented online conferences, journal clubs, case reviews, and question banks for fellows ( Table 1) . We have also instituted measures like mandated days off to recuperate, back-up fellows, and daily check-ins. On-line meditation classes and "remote" happy hours have been employed.

Every evening, the eerie silence that fills our city is replaced by collective applause from people all over, in an effort to give thanks for the work we do. Restaurants are donating food, others are donating handmade hats, mask, and shields for PPE. These measures are deeply meaningful and they are the fuel that keeps us moving each day.
These are trying times, but HCWs and trainees will continue to persevere and we will get through them. On the other side of this crisis, the rest of our lives and careers await.
